sentences.sentence: Emissions The scheme's carbon pricing model will minimise the risk of wasted resources and rent-seeking.We take comfort from the considerable discussion in The Australian Financial Review since our National Press Club presentation on Australia's "superpower" opportunity that informed opinion agrees at least on the need for carbon pricing.In criticising our proposals, the Financial Review's economics editor, John Kehoe, emphasised the risks of arbitrary interventions which can result in wasted resources and rent-seeking behaviour.We emphatically share that concern.

Our proposals are therefore directed at minimising those risks by focusing on programs with little bureaucratic discretion, that deal with clearly identified externalities, and that focus on developing energy-intensive export industries where Australia is most likely to have an enduring comparative advantage.Where there are large external costs and benefits, such as with climate change, private market activity left to itself is certain to pick losers, as well as imposing costs on the economy by emitting greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
The efficient solution is a charge equal to the cost that the emitting firm imposes on others.

That solution raises government revenue.At the same time, there is one huge external benefit in the early stages of such a rapid low carbon transition: the knowledge that an early investor in new industries and processes confers on those who follow.
The solution is a payment for the knowledge that the early mover cannot capture for itself.

That costs government revenue.The Carmody carbon price revived by John Kehoe was proposed as an alternative to the Emissions Trading Scheme that was legislated on the initiative of the Gillard government.

The Gillard version had the advantage of linking smoothly to the European ETS, and would have done so on July 1, 2014 if the Abbott government had not abolished the system the day before.Geoff Carmody's carbon price would only be paid on emissions from goods consumed in Australia, so it would exempt our exports.

This would prevent our exports of zero-carbon products gaining an advantage under the European Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism; since exports are not subject to an equivalent carbon price, they would still be subject to the European levy.Carmody's carbon pricing does not deal with the negative externality that would otherwise hold back our green energy-intensive exports.
The Carbon Solutions Levy that we favour would secure entry into external markets for zero-carbon Australian goods.
It also would raise considerable revenue.

Revenue matters because Australia needs a strong budget to keep the cost of capital low, to ensure a competitive real exchange rate and to protect against external shocks.The levy is administratively simpler and has much lower compliance and other transactions costs than the Gillard and Carmody versions of the ETS.Critics writing in the Financial Review have said it would reduce Australian exports of coal and gas and likely raise world emissions.
Work at The Superpower Institute will assess that claim, and compare the levy's many benefits with the limited costs.

For example, if world prices do not change, the levy will be paid to a considerable extent from pure profits, which happen to be subject to much lower mining and gas taxes than in Australia's main competitors.Production would fall only from the highest-cost mines that contribute least to people's incomes.
Australia is the dominant exporter of metallurgical coal, so the world price would rise to some extent.

That would reduce any hit to Australian production, while increasing incentives for replacing coal-based iron with Australian green iron.Our proposed Superpower Industries Innovation Scheme seeks to provide a clear and simple framework to reward early innovators for benefits they confer on others, while preserving the maximum role for private competitive initiative.

The focus on energy-intensive industries in which Australia has a clear advantage, and based on an identified externality, greatly limits the scope for waste and rent-seeking.Our proposal for implementation of the government's Capacity Investment Scheme - in which the government will underwrite private investment in renewable and clean dispatchable energy - is not an argument for the CIS, as Kehoe suggested.
The government has already decided that it will be introduced.Its introduction is one more unhappy consequence of seeking to compensate for the absence of carbon pricing.
We noted the risks of dangerously large claims on the budget from the CIS, and of shifting resource allocation decisions from competitive private markets to government officials.
Our proposal simply seeks to minimise these risks.
We want investment decisions taken by the private sector.

We do not want government officials deciding which investments proceed and where.Knowledge and public discussion provided essential underpinnings for the reforms of the 1980s and 1990s, which set up nearly a quarter of a century of rising Australian productivity and incomes.

The Financial Review played a vital role in carrying the necessary information and providing a platform for debate of alternative proposals.A new era of stronger productivity growth and rising living standards is possible today through comparable discussion of how Australia can make good use of its "superpower" opportunity through market-based mechanisms that deal with clear externalities.Ross Garnaut founded, and Rod Sims chairs, The Superpower Institute.
